attributes.title: social isolation and vocabulary development
attributes.description: A convincing body of research has shown that stimulating home environments and routines, including e.g., shared book reading, in early childhood promotes language development. The current longitudinal study aims to assess home activities and interactions that parents engage in with their 16 to 36-month-old infants during the period of social isolation in the United States (in South Florida in particular), and to examine the role of those activities in early vocabulary development of American infants across varying in SES and language background (English monolingual, Spanish bilingual, English-Spanish bilingual).

q2.value:
First, we hypothesize that vocabulary development during the period of isolation will be slower than vocabulary development during a period of non-isolation for age and sex matched controls. 
Second, we expect that these differences in the rate of vocabulary development will relate to changes in home and school routines. For example, we expect that during isolation, families’ relative amounts of shared book reading versus screen time may change. We hypothesize that for those children who have relatively higher amounts of screen time and less shared book reading will have smaller gains in their vocabulary sizes than infants with less screen time and more shared book reading. We also expect that for children who typically attend daycare or preschool, shifts in routines and effects on vocabulary will be stronger than for children who have in-home care which was less or uninterrupted. 
Third, we hypothesize that bilingual children may have the largest shifts in their in-home routines with respect to their exposure to each of their languages. Context influences language exposure for many bilingual learners (e.g., Spanish at home and English at school). As such, we expect variation in their gains in each language (e.g., English to be slower during this period).

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The study has a regression design: we will examine whether family's SES, language background, frequency of shared book reading, structured play, screen time, and changes to sleep and stress levels predict gains in expressive vocabulary sizes.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will contact, by the means of social media and lists of interested families, American parents (focusing on the South Florida region, and Miami-Dade county in particular) having children from 16 and 24 months of age (at Time 1) and will invite them to take part in the current longitudinal study by filling in a questionnaire at Time - 1 (at the beginning of the home lockdown) and at Time - 2 (at the end of the lockdown period). The questionnaires are hosted on Web-CDI and Qualtrics. The questionnaires will include a language questionnaire (the American English and/or Spanish MCDI words and sentences), a family background questionnaire (that will include information about siblings' gender and age and family's SES), and questions about the type (and frequency) of activities did parents engage in with their child during the quarantine period. The language questionnaire will provide us with an estimate of a child's vocabulary size at Time 1 and Time 2. The following child inclusion criteria will be used: a child was born at term or less than two weeks before term, a child did not have (or does not have) auditory or visual deficits, a child is exposed to no more than 10% of a language other than English and/or Spanish. Following the ending of social isolation, a control group, matching the target group in age and sex will be recruited to compare vocabulary development during the same period of time.

q11.value: We will stop data collection of the target group as soon as coronavirus social distancing is finished in South Florida. Given our previous research, we expect a 10-15% of response rate. We will aim to invite as many participants as possible. Following the ending of social isolation, a control group, matching the target group in age and sex will be recruited to compare vocabulary development during the same period of time.

question.value: Our dependent variable is the change in the total number of words that parents would have reported their child produces from T1 to T2. We will also explore changes in a child’s percentile, based on normative data (adjusted for age and gender) as a dependent variable. Our predictors are: SES (maternal education), language background (bilingual versus monolingual), the frequency of shared book reading during the quarantine period; the frequency of structured child-parent interactions, the amount of screen time, amount of sleep, perceived stress. We will also count the number of days between T1 and T2 and will include it as a covariate in the analyses.

First, we will examine the number of participants and the distribution of the SES backgrounds. If the distribution is not homogeneous and we have relatively few answers per category (less than 5), then we will recode the SES variable into a binary factor (low [from 0 to 2], and high [from 3 to 5]). Language background will be coded categorically (English monolingual, Spanish monolingual, English-Spanish bilingual). We will define bilingual as any child having between 30-70% exposure to each language. Exploratory analyses will also examine language background continuously using the % exposure to each language as a predictor of vocabulary growth in each language. Then, we will examine the role of different activities parents have engaged in during the quarantine period and the gain score in the vocabulary size. We will also include Gap_days as a covariate in the analyses, as we expect larger gains of more days have passed between Time 1 and Time 2. In a separate series of analyses, we will examine differences in everyday activities across families from different SES backgrounds. If the data permits (see above), then correlation analyses will be performed between Maternal_educ (6 categories, coded as a continuous variable) and the frequency of different activities during the lockdown period; if not, then a binary factor of SES will be used and then all the data will be split in two (families with high and families with low SES).

q18.value:
For each child, the vocabulary size at Time 1 will be subtracted from the vocabulary size at Time 2. Theses gain scores will be used in the statistical analyses. If we observe that some children have close-to-ceiling vocabulary size at Time 1, then we will standardize the vocabulary score at both times and a standardized measure of gains will be used in the analyses: (voc_std(T2)-voc_std(T1)). 
Inference criteria

q22.value: In the exploratory analyses, we will examine the role of outdoor activities (type and frequency) in children's well-being and self-regulation. In addition, we will examine whether there are differences between those infants who already attended an early-care center /preschool before social isolation measures and those who did not.

registration_responses.q2:
First, we hypothesize that vocabulary development during the period of isolation will be slower than vocabulary development during a period of non-isolation for age and sex matched controls. 
Second, we expect that these differences in the rate of vocabulary development will relate to changes in home and school routines. For example, we expect that during isolation, families’ relative amounts of shared book reading versus screen time may change. We hypothesize that for those children who have relatively higher amounts of screen time and less shared book reading will have smaller gains in their vocabulary sizes than infants with less screen time and more shared book reading. We also expect that for children who typically attend daycare or preschool, shifts in routines and effects on vocabulary will be stronger than for children who have in-home care which was less or uninterrupted. 
Third, we hypothesize that bilingual children may have the largest shifts in their in-home routines with respect to their exposure to each of their languages. Context influences language exposure for many bilingual learners (e.g., Spanish at home and English at school). As such, we expect variation in their gains in each language (e.g., English to be slower during this period).

q4: No blinding is involved in this study.

attributes.title: PAP for Interrupted Time Series/Difference in Difference Study of Female-Only Police Stations in India

q1.value: PAP for Interrupted Time Series/Difference in Difference Study of Female-Only Police Stations in India

q9.value: I am filing this PAP after analysis of crime report data in Bihar and Uttar Pradesh but prior to data acquired from Haryana’s police department. Thus, I am blind to results from Haryana’s women’s police stations at this time.

registration_responses.q1: PAP for Interrupted Time Series/Difference in Difference Study of Female-Only Police Stations in India
registration_responses.q9: I am filing this PAP after analysis of crime report data in Bihar and Uttar Pradesh but prior to data acquired from Haryana’s police department. Thus, I am blind to results from Haryana’s women’s police stations at this time.

attributes.title: Adjusting to the COVID-19 Outbreak in the United States: The Role of Personality and Situational Factors on the Maintenance of Habitual Behaviors
attributes.description: The COVID-19 outbreak and associated policies meant to reduce the spread of the virus have imposed many changes to the lives of people living in the United States. On top of working or attending classes from home, many families are now dealing with uncertain job prospects or limited income, reduced work or school hours, limited or unavailable childcare during the day, and limited access to food or healthcare items. At the same time, when living in cities where lockdown or stay-at-home orders are in place, many people have unlimited access to food, smoking, drinking, television and mobile devices. This suggests that the conditions imposed by the outbreak are affecting many health-promoting and health-damaging behaviors, including eating, sleep, substance use, and screen time. Our goal is to uncover (1) what types of lifestyle challenges people have been facing during their adaptation to the COVID-19 outbreak, and (2) the extent to which personality (e.g., self-control) and situational factors (i.e., local policies and lock down orders) predict the development of new habits, and changes in health behaviors, such as smoking, drinking, using social media, exercising, sleeping, and eating healthily.

q1.value: Fernanda Chardulo Dias De Andrade, Hoyle Lab

q2.value:
As policies aimed at containing the spread of the coronavirus have been put in place, contextual factors have changed and people are being faced with unusual circumstances that have eliminated their usual cues, requiring the exercise of self-control to maintain their usual behaviors. We hypothesize that, the more people’s lives have been disrupted by the outbreak, the stronger the relationship between self-control and their behaviors. 

We also hypothesize that the stronger the level of participants' self-control, self-regulation, and conscientiousness, the more likely they are to have established new habits, and the less their behaviors and habits will have to have changed. This will be especially important for those whose lives have been more severely disrupted, as their personality may buffer against maladaptive health behaviors.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: We plan to recruit approximately 550 participants across all three mediums.

question.value:
- Location
- State and city policies in place to prevent spread of coronavirus
- Pre-outbreak habits (multiple choice, (Adapted from the Creature of Habit Scale (COHS, Ersche et al., 2017))
- Pre-outbreak daily life summary (open ended)
- Self-report habits index-Short version (Morean et al., 2018)
-- Checking phone
-- Regular sleep habits
-- Exercising or physical activity
-- Balanced diet
- Capacity for Self-Control Scale (Hoyle & Davisson, 2016)
- The Emotion Regulation Questionnaire (Gross & John, 2003)
- Big Five Inventory-2, Conscientiousness Subscale (Soto & John, 2017)
- Psychological Effects of the Outbreak (adapted from the Research on Adolescent Risk and Resilience (RAISE), Hoyle et al.)
- Work and Life Effects of the Outbreak (created for study)
- Behavior Changes Since the Outbreak (created for study)
- Post-outbreak habits index (Adapted from the Creature of Habit Scale (COHS, Ersche et al., 2017)
- Habits Reinstatement Measure (created for this study)
- Demographics Items
- Perceived vulnerability to COVID

We will average each measure's items according to scale instructions, transform (e.g., square root) variables if necessary due to skew or kurtosis, compute scores for behavior changes, local disruptions, work and life effects of the outbreak.

We will perform hierarchical multiple regressions with demographic variables in step 1, local policies  in step 2, self-regulation, self-control and conscientiousness in step 3, interaction terms in step 4, and habit changes and reinstatement, behavior changes, psychological effects of the outbreak, and work and life effects of the outbreak as outcomes.

q19.value: p < .05, CIs that do not contain 0, will be considered statistically significant.

q20.value: Data will be excluded if we find evidence of nonsense responding, suspicious answering patterns, negative or below .10 person-total correlations.

registration_responses.q1: Fernanda Chardulo Dias De Andrade, Hoyle Lab

As policies aimed at containing the spread of the coronavirus have been put in place, contextual factors have changed and people are being faced with unusual circumstances that have eliminated their usual cues, requiring the exercise of self-control to maintain their usual behaviors. We hypothesize that, the more people’s lives have been disrupted by the outbreak, the stronger the relationship between self-control and their behaviors. 

We also hypothesize that the stronger the level of participants' self-control, self-regulation, and conscientiousness, the more likely they are to have established new habits, and the less their behaviors and habits will have to have changed. This will be especially important for those whose lives have been more severely disrupted, as their personality may buffer against maladaptive health behaviors.

attributes.title: Does Spinal Manipulative Therapy Impact the Immune System?  A Rapid Review of the Literature
attributes.description:
This is a protocol for a rapid review of the literature, using WHO Rapid Review Methods, to investigate the the impact of spinal manipulation on the immune system.

Principal investigator: Pierre Côté, Faculty of Health Sciences and Centre for Disability Prevention and Rehabilitation at Ontario Tech University and CMCC, Ontario Tech University, Faculty of Health Sciences, 2000 Simcoe St N, Oshawa, ON L1G 0C5

Review team members: Pierre Côté, Carol Cancelliere, Silvano Mior, Ngai Chow, Anne Taylor-Vaisey, Stephen Injeyan, Julita Teodorczyk-Injeyan, J. David Cassidy

summary.value:
Start date:  April 13, 2020

Anticipated completion date:  July 31, 2020

Funding sources/sponsors: College of Chiropractors of British Columbia

Research Questions

1.	Is spinal manipulative therapy (manipulation or mobilization) efficacious in preventing the development of infectious diseases in healthy individuals?
2.	Is spinal manipulative therapy (manipulation or mobilization) effective in preventing the development of infectious diseases in healthy individuals?
3.	Is spinal manipulative therapy (manipulation or mobilization) efficacious in improving disease-specific health outcomes in patients with infectious disease? 
4.	Is spinal manipulative therapy (manipulation or mobilization) effective in improving disease-specific health outcomes in patients with infectious disease?
5.	Compared to no intervention, sham or placebo interventions, is spinal manipulative therapy (manipulation or mobilization) associated with changes in the level or concentration of immunological biomarkers?

METHODS

Data Sources and Search Strategy: We will systematically search MEDLINE, CINAHL, EMBASE, Index to Chiropractic Literature, and Cochrane Central from inception to date. We will restrict our search to papers published in English. 

Condition being studied: Infectious diseases.

Target population: 1) Healthy children and adults treated with spinal manipulation or mobilization to prevent the development of infectious diseases. 2) Children and adults with infectious diseases treated with spinal manipulation or mobilization.

Interventions: Spinal manipulation includes techniques incorporating a high-velocity, low amplitude impulse or thrust applied at or near the end of a joint’s passive range of motion.1 Spinal mobilization includes techniques incorporating a low-velocity and varying amplitude oscillatory movement within a joint’s passive range of motion.1,2 Spinal manipulation and mobilization involve manual and mechanically-assisted procedures.3

Comparators/controls: Placebo, sham manual therapies, wait listing, usual care, no interventions, medication and other therapies.

Types of study to be included:  We will include cohort studies and randomized controlled trials (RCTs) that evaluated the prevention and/or management of infection or infectious disease, or changes in the level or concentration of immunological biomarkers, in children and adults (both healthy and symptomatic) who received spinal manipulation or mobilization. 

Types of study not considered: We will exclude case reports, case series, case-control studies, cross-sectional studies, qualitative studies, systematic reviews and meta-analyses, guidelines, guideline statements, letters, editorials, commentaries, unpublished manuscripts, dissertations, government reports, books and book chapters, conference proceedings, meeting abstracts, study protocols, lectures and addresses, consensus development statements, cadaveric, and laboratory or animal studies.

Outcomes: We will investigate both clinical outcomes and immunological biomarkers. Clinical outcomes include: incidence of infection or infectious disease, or changes in disease-specific outcomes. An immunological biomarker is a “characteristic that is objectively measured and evaluated as an indicator of normal biological processes, pathogenic processes, or pharmacologic responses to a therapeutic intervention.”4 For this review, we are interested in the following immunological biomarkers: interleukins (IL-1β, IL- 2, IL- 6, IL- 10, interleukin 1 receptor antagonist (IL 1RA), tumor necrosis factor (TNFα), interferon (IFNγ),  chemotactic cytokines (CCL2, CCL3, CCL4); other indicators of inflammatory response (e.g. soluble tumor necrosis factor receptors 1 and 2  (sTNFR)), neuropeptides  (e.g. substance P), C-reactive protein, and immunoglobulins (IgG, IgM, IgE).

Study selection: A trained investigator will conduct all of the screening for eligible articles using standardized pilot-test forms with detailed instructions. Prior to title and abstract screening, we will validate the quality of screening. Ten percent of all eligible articles will be randomly selected and the titles and abstracts of these articles will be screened independently by a second experienced investigator. A 95% level of agreement is required between two reviewers before moving to full screening of titles and abstracts. Disagreements between the two reviewers will be resolved by reaching consensus through discussion or by a third reviewer if needed. Once the 95% agreement is achieved, one reviewer will complete screening of titles and abstracts and full texts. 

Risk of bias assessment: One reviewer will independently assess risk of bias of included studies using the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN) criteria for RCTs and cohort studies.5,6 

We will include a quality control step in the critical appraisal of studies. The reviewer who assesses the risk of bias of the studies will present a summary of the critically appraised papers to experienced methodologists who will validate the outcome of the appraisals. Studies will be rated as high quality, acceptable, low quality or unacceptable.  We will restrict our synthesis to studies that were judged to be of high and acceptable quality. 

Data extraction: On reviewer will extract data from low risk of bias studies to build evidence stables stratified by research objective. Data extraction will be validated by one of three reviewers. We will collect information regarding study characteristics, (i.e. author name, year of publication, study design, sample size, length of follow up), participant characteristics (i.e., age, indications for treatment or condition treated, and location), intervention characteristics (i.e., description of interventions and comparison groups), and outcome data (i.e., incidence of infection or infectious disease, disease-specific outcomes, changes in immunological biomarkers).

Evidence Synthesis and Statistical Analysis: We will synthesize the evidence of low risk of bias studies according to the Synthesis without Meta-Analysis (SWiM) Guideline.7 When data are available, we will compute the incidence (and 95% confidence intervals (CI)) of infection or infectious disease from RCTs and cohort studies. Incidence will be measured by calculating the number of new cases of infection or infectious disease in a group divided by the total number of participants in the same group.8 Confidence intervals will be calculated using incidence of infection or infectious disease in each group, total number of participants in each group, and α = 0.05.

Dissemination plan: The College of Chiropractors of British Columbia will use this review to inform regulatory policy decisions regarding the use of spinal manipulation and mobilization to impact immune function.  The results of the rapid review will be published in the peer-reviewed literature.

Keywords: Spinal manipulation, spinal mobilization, immunity, infectious disease 

References

1.	Rubinstein SM, Terwee CB, Assendelft WJ, et al. Spinal manipulative therapy for acute low-back pain. Cochrane Database Syst Rev 2012;9:CD008880.
2.	Maitland G HE, Banks K, English K Maitland’s Vertebral Manipulation. 7 ed. Toronto: Elsevier Butterworth Heinemann; 2005.
3.	Bergmann TF, Peterson DH, Lawrence DJ. Chiropractic Technique. Churchill Livingstone Inc., NY, 1993.
4.	Biomarkers Definitions Working Group. Biomarkers and surrogate endpoints: preferred definitions and conceptual framework. Clin Pharmacol Ther. 2001;69(3):89–95. doi:10.1067/mcp.2001.113989.
5.	Harbour R, Miller K. A new system for grading recommendations in evidence based guidelines. Br Med J (Clinical Res Ed). 2001;323:334–6.
6.	Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network Critical Appraisal: Notes and checklists. 2013. http://www.sign.ac.uk/methodology/checklists.html#. Accessed 16 Apr 2020.
7.	Campbell M, McKenzie JE, Sowden A, et al. Synthesis without meta-analysis (SWiM) in systematic reviews: reporting guideline. BMJ. 2020;368:l6890. Published 2020 Jan 16. doi:10.1136/bmj.l6890
8.	Fletcher RH, Fletcher SW, Wagner EH. Clinical epidemiology the essentials. Third edit. Baltimore: Williams & Wilkins; 1996.

Studies will be rated as high quality, acceptable, low quality or unacceptable.  We will restrict our synthesis to studies that were judged to be of high and acceptable quality. 

Data extraction: On reviewer will extract data from low risk of bias studies to build evidence stables stratified by research objective. Data extraction will be validated by one of three reviewers. We will collect information regarding study characteristics, (i.e. author name, year of publication, study design, sample size, length of follow up), participant characteristics (i.e., age, indications for treatment or condition treated, and location), intervention characteristics (i.e., description of interventions and comparison groups), and outcome data (i.e., incidence of infection or infectious disease, disease-specific outcomes, changes in immunological biomarkers).

Evidence Synthesis and Statistical Analysis: We will synthesize the evidence of low risk of bias studies according to the Synthesis without Meta-Analysis (SWiM) Guideline.7 When data are available, we will compute the incidence (and 95% confidence intervals (CI)) of infection or infectious disease from RCTs and cohort studies. Incidence will be measured by calculating the number of new cases of infection or infectious disease in a group divided by the total number of participants in the same group.8 Confidence intervals will be calculated using incidence of infection or infectious disease in each group, total number of participants in each group, and α = 0.05.

Dissemination plan: The College of Chiropractors of British Columbia will use this review to inform regulatory policy decisions regarding the use of spinal manipulation and mobilization to impact immune function.  The results of the rapid review will be published in the peer-reviewed literature.

Keywords: Spinal manipulation, spinal mobilization, immunity, infectious disease 

References

1.	Rubinstein SM, Terwee CB, Assendelft WJ, et al. Spinal manipulative therapy for acute low-back pain. Cochrane Database Syst Rev 2012;9:CD008880.
2.	Maitland G HE, Banks K, English K Maitland’s Vertebral Manipulation. 7 ed. Toronto: Elsevier Butterworth Heinemann; 2005.
3.	Bergmann TF, Peterson DH, Lawrence DJ. Chiropractic Technique. Churchill Livingstone Inc., NY, 1993.
4.	Biomarkers Definitions Working Group. Biomarkers and surrogate endpoints: preferred definitions and conceptual framework. Clin Pharmacol Ther. 2001;69(3):89–95. doi:10.1067/mcp.2001.113989.
5.	Harbour R, Miller K. A new system for grading recommendations in evidence based guidelines. Br Med J (Clinical Res Ed). 2001;323:334–6.
6.	Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network Critical Appraisal: Notes and checklists. 2013. http://www.sign.ac.uk/methodology/checklists.html#. Accessed 16 Apr 2020.
7.	Campbell M, McKenzie JE, Sowden A, et al. Synthesis without meta-analysis (SWiM) in systematic reviews: reporting guideline. BMJ. 2020;368:l6890. Published 2020 Jan 16. doi:10.1136/bmj.l6890
8.	Fletcher RH, Fletcher SW, Wagner EH. Clinical epidemiology the essentials. Third edit. Baltimore: Williams & Wilkins; 1996.

attributes.title: PENYEMBUNYIAN PESAN RAHASIA PADA CITRA DIGITAL DENGAN TEKNIK STEGANOGRAFI MENGGUNAKAN METODE LEAST SIGNIFICANT BIT ( LSB ).
attributes.description:
Seiring dengan semakin berharganya nilai sebuah informasi dan semakin banyak sumber-sumber informasi, maka semakin banyak pula kebutuhan manusia untuk dapat menemukan informasi yang sesuai keperluannya dengan cepat. Information Retrieval (Perolehan Informasi) merupakan suatu pencarian informasi(biasanya berupa dokumen) yang didasarkan pada suatu query (inputan user) yang diharapkan dapat memenuhi keinginan user dari dokumen yang ada. Dua aspek penting dalam konsep Information Retrieval yang diterapkan dalam sebuah perancangan mesin pencari yaitu repesentasi dari informasi dan pengukuran yang akan mengukur nilai kesamaan antara dua obyek. Informasi yang dapat direpresentasikan menjadi sebuah obyek yang direpresentasikan dalam berbagai bentuk dan model (heterogeneous). Keadaan ini mengakibatkan bahwa pencarian untuk suatu obyek informasi yang diinginkan akan dapat dipetakan kepada beberapa obyek informati yang dinilai relevan. Relevansi dua informasi di-ukur dari keberadaan kata kunci (keyword) dan bobotnya. Konsekuensi logis atas keadaan ini adalah bahwa dalam melakukan pencarian obyek yang diinginkan, ditemukan terdapat ketidakpastian (uncertainly) terhadap penggunaan keyword pada query oleh pengguna dengan keberadaan keyword pada dokumen. Pada penelitian ini akan difokuskan pada studi efektifitas vektor model dengan menggunakan algoritma steming poter untuk membentuk kata-kata menjadi sebuah kata baku  
serta pembobotan frekuwensi term untuk menentukan tingkat kepentingan setiap indeks term dalam sebuah dokumen dan fungsi kesamaan cosine dalam mengukur kemiripan queri dengan dokumen. Hasil pengujian nilai kualitas rata-rata precesion dan recall bahwa untuk semua bentuk query pencarian dokumen  mempunyai nilai precesion 100% artinya baik pencarian berdasarkan bentuk query isi, judul dan dokumen mempunyai precesion yang baik sedangkan hasil pengujian recall menunjukkan hasil yang berbeda, dimana pencarian berdasarkan bentuk queri isi dokumen menempati recall tertinggi sebesar 90%, sedangkan pencarian berdasarkan bentuk queri judul dokumen dengan nilai recall 70% dan pencarian berdasarkan bentuk query dokumen menempati posisi terendah dengan recall 33%.
tags: steganografi, multimedia, penyisipan informasi, simple LSB substitution

attributes.title: Creativity and Ethics 8
attributes.description: This is an experiment examining the relationship between creative idea generation and helping behaviours.
attributes.withdrawal_justification: There was an error during registration. It was meant to be an experimental study, not an observational/archival study.

attributes.title: Mental and Physical Health outcomes of Mindfulness: An Umbrella Review of Meta-Analyses of Randomized Controlled Trials
attributes.description: Mental and Physical Health outcomes of Mindfulness: An Umbrella Review of Meta-Analyses

q1.value: Liye Zou, Jieting Zhang, Chunxiao Li, Yanjie Zhang, Jane Jie Yu, Lin Jingyuan, Qian YU, Xinli Chi, Tao Xiao, Qi Zhao, Lina Wang, Cuimei Yang, Paolo Fusar-Poli, Ai Koyanagi Parc Sanitari Sant Joan de Déu, Jaeil Shin, Elena Dragioti, Giovanni Castellini, Fernanda Cunha Soares, Joe Firth, Amedeo Minichino, Ovidiu Alexinschi, Edoardo Giuseppe Ostinelli, Lee Smith, Nicola Veronese, Albert Yeung, Lin Yang, Marco Solmi, Luca Bodini

q2.value: Mindfulness will improve mental and physical health, compared with inactive and/or active comparators.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Five electronic databases (PubMed, Embase, PsycINFO, SCOPUS, and Cochrane library database) will be systematically searched from inception to January 2020 for meta-analyses of randomized controlled trials investigating associations between mindfulness and health outcomes. Two groups of search terms will be used as follow: (mindfulness* OR “meditation” OR “mindfulness-based” OR “MBSR” OR “MBCT” OR “M-BCT” OR “Zen” OR “mindful* OR “relaxation therapy” OR “savoring” OR “mantra” OR “acceptance-based” OR “acceptance and commitment therapy” OR “dialectical behavior therapy”) AND (“Meta-Analysis” OR “meta-an*” OR “systematic review”).  

Additionally, potentially relevant reviews in reference lists of retrieved systematic reviews will be manually searched. All initially searched items will be exported to Endnote where duplicates can be automatically identified. If some of duplicate cannot be picked up, we will manually assess by comparing title and abstract. Two researchers will independently perform literature search, followed by article selection through screening title and abstract of all initially retrieved items and then select potentially eligible articles for full-text review for eligibility. A third reviewer will be invited for discussion if case of any disagreement. 

Only peer-review articles published in English will be included in this umbrella review if they included systematic reviews with meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials investigating the impact of mindfulness-based interventions on health outcomes. Furthermore, those meta-analyses of randomized controlled trials must include: (1) human subjects regardless of health status and age; (2) mindfulness as the main component of an intervention program, defined by authors of independent meta-analysis; (3) active control and/or non-active control; (4) at least one health outcome. We will also exclude systematic reviews without a quantitative meta-analytic synthesis of data, narrative reviews, and letters to the editor. Reasons for exclusion will be annotated after full text assessment (i.e. no individual study data, no outcome, no meta-analysis…etc.).

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value: Only peer-review articles published in English will be included in this umbrella review if they included systematic reviews with meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials investigating the impact of mindfulness-based interventions on health outcomes. Furthermore, those meta-analyses of randomized controlled trials must include: (1) human subjects regardless of health status and age; (2) mindfulness as the main component of an intervention program, defined by authors of independent meta-analysis; (3) active control and/or non-active control; (4) at least one health outcome. We will also exclude systematic reviews without a quantitative meta-analytic synthesis of data, narrative reviews, and letters to the editor. Reasons for exclusion will be annotated after full text assessment (i.e. no individual study data, no outcome, no meta-analysis…etc.).

Primary outcome will be evidence on efficacy on the primary symptoms/parameters of targeted condition (i.e. depression, anxiety, stress, distress, burnout, fatigue, pain, blood pressure), compared with active and/or non-active comparators.
Co-primary outcome will be testing whether mindfulness is a trans-diagnostic intervention following TRANS-D recommendations. 

Secondary outcomes will be safety outcomes, including drop-out rates, and evidence on other than primary outcomes (e.g., insomnia, well-being, life satisfaction) as reported in the included meta-analyses.

For each eligible meta-analysis, two researchers (LZ and JZ) will independently extract data: PubMed ID (PMID), first author, journal name, year of publication, number of included studies, study population, score of methodological quality assessment based on AMSTAR 2, setting and description of the intervention (type of mindfulness, frequency and duration of sessions, and duration of whole treatment), control type, and outcome of interest. 
If there is more than one combination of population, intervention, control and outcome of interest in a meta-analytical review, we will assess them separately.  Additionally, if both main and subgroup-analysis will be presented in meta-analysis paper, we will select both. Notably, we will select a meta-analysis paper including the largest number of RCTs if more than one article reported same outcome of interest in the same population, intervention, and control.
For re-analysis of summary effect size for each psychological health outcome, we will further extract useful data from individual RCTs of each association, including geographic location of the study, type of metric (standardized mean difference, mean difference, Cohen’s d, and/or Hedge’s g) and its specific value along with the corresponding confidence interval, and the number of cases/participant, as well as the mean age of participants, whether the outcome was assessed at endpoint or at follow-up. For each individual RCT, we will also assign the mindfulness intervention either to “warp” or “weft” group, as recently proposed.

For each meta-analysis, we will estimate the summary effect size and its 95% CI through random-effects models. We will also estimate the prediction interval and its 95% CI, which further accounts for between-study effects, and estimates the certainty of the association if a new study addresses that same association. For the largest dataset of each meta-analysis, we will calculate the SE of the effect size. If the SE is less than 0.1 then the 95% CI would be lower than 0.20 (which is less than the magnitude of a small effect size). We will calculate between-study heterogeneity using the I-squared metric, with I-Squared of 50% and 75% that represents high and very high heterogeneity, respectively.  

Finally, we applied the Ioannidis’ excess of significance test. In brief, this test evaluates whether the number of studies with nominally significant results (i.e. with p<0.05) among those included in a meta-analysis is too large based on the power that these data sets have to detect effects at α=0.05. The power estimate for each data set was calculated. The sum of the power estimates of each study provides the expected (E) number of data sets with nominal statistical significance. As described elsewhere, the number of expected ‘positive’ (i.e., statistically significant) datasets can be compared with the observed (O) number of statistically significant studies through a χ2-based test. The larger the difference between O and E, the higher the degree of excess of significance bias. The true effect size of a meta-analysis is unknown. We considered the effect size of the largest dataset (i.e., with the lower SE), and based on this we estimated the effect sizes of each constituent study with an algorithm using a non-central t distribution. Excess significance for single meta-analysis was considered whenever p < 0.10. The O versus E comparison was done separately for each meta-analysis but was extended to groups including many meta-analyses after summing the O and E values of each individual meta-analysis.

We will conduct sensitivity analyses to investigate the role of mindfulness definition, sticking to criteria proposed in, ad focusing separately on “warp” and “weft” definitions of mindfulness, as defined in individual RCTs. We will also run sensitivity analyses on RCTs vs inactive and vs active control interventions separately. Also, we will run sensitivity analyses according to RCTs countries, namely Eastern (China, Taiwan, Japan) vs Western countries. Finally, we will run sensitivity analyses based on mean age of participants of individual RCTs (<24, 24-65, >65 years old). Sensitivity for endpoint and follow-up assessment will be performed as well.

q20.value: Two researchers will independently search title/abstracts for eligibility, and when a consensus could not be reached a third researcher will be consulted. The full-texts of potentially eligible article will then be retrieved, and the same research will independently check each study for eligibility. If any disagreement exists, a third researcher emerges to solve this issue.

attributes.title: Public reactions to anti-knife carrying messages.
attributes.description:
Over the years, police and anti-knife carrying organisations have tried different methods to proactively encourage individuals not to carry weapons, but despite this, knife enabled crime continues to rise. Anti-knife crime campaigns frequently highlight the risks associated with such behaviour, specifically that people are more likely to be seriously injured or killed themselves if they carry a knife.

In line with Terror Management Theory, mortality salience research has indicated that if one’s mortality is made salient, one is more likely to engage in behaviours to protect oneself and preserve self-esteem. Highlighting the possibility of death due to carrying a knife may actually accentuate positive views around knife carrying as individuals feel the need to protect themselves. Yet, these views may be negated when mortality salience is primed with responsibility. Encouraging individuals to think about the effects of knife carrying on others (primed responsibility), rather than the effect on themselves, may reverse the effects of mortality salience. If primed responsibility leads to less positive views about carrying a knife, police and anti-knife carrying organisations may be able to design more successful communication strategies, which has implications for policy makers.

This study is being run during unprecedented times, when the country is amid the covid-19 crisis, making mortality more salient than usual for some. The present context may impact on the results.

q1.value: Dr Zoe Hobson, Ben Bradford, Julia Yesberg

q2.value:
It is hypothesised that:
1.	Viewing campaign images that highlight you are more likely to be killed if you carry a knife, and thus being subjected to mortality salience, will increase positive thoughts in relation to knife carrying once it is outside of their focal attention.
a)	The effect of mortality salience will be greater among those who report high behaviour-specific (knife carrying) self-esteem and cultural worldviews. 
b)	The effect of mortality salience will encourage greater risk-taking behaviours around knife carrying.

2.	Providing subjects with a message making them aware of the consequences of knife carrying on others close to them, will reverse any adverse effect of mortality salience and reduce their positive thoughts in relation to carrying a knife.

3.	However, in the present context (as of April 2020), those more affected by the Covid-19 crisis - i.e. for whom mortality is already more salient for that reason - will be less affected by the images.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: We are creating a 2 (Image: Knife-related vs neutral) x 3 (Message: Likelihood of death vs Primed responsibility vs no message) between-subjects design.

q7.value: We will use simple randomisation, where each participnat will be randomly assigned to see either block of images (knife related or neutral images) and then randomly assigned to receive one of the three messages. The randomisation will be automatically assigned through the online survey platform.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will be using Prolific Academic to collect our data. Subjects need to be resident in the UK, male and aged between 18 and 25 years of age.

q11.value: In total, we aim to have a sample of 480 subjects. This will provide 80 subjects in each condition.

question.value: We will manipulate the type of social media campaign seen and the message presented. There are two levels of the social media campaign images: knife related or neutral. There are three levels of the message variable which are: death related message, primed responsibility message or no message.

Outcome variables: Perceptions of behaviour for their own self esteem; extent to which carrying a knife was endorsed by their cultural world view; individuals’ risk perception of knife carrying, both in relation to themselves and to others; willingness to carry knife.
Manipulation check: accessibility to death related content.
Co-variates: ethnicity, previous knife experience, victimisation, covid-19 experience.

Independent t-tests will assess differences of death related words accessed by likelihood of death (mortality salience) condition compared to neutral condition. A one-way ANOVA will assess any difference caused the by message presented after the campaigns (likelihood of death, primed responsibility or control). Further ANOVAs will look at both between and within groups for knife carrying self esteem and cultural world views and how these impact on risk perceptions and willingness to carry a knife. Responses to the covid-19 related questions will be used as an factor to.

registration_responses.q1: Dr Zoe Hobson, Ben Bradford, Julia Yesberg
registration_responses.q2:
It is hypothesised that:
1.	Viewing campaign images that highlight you are more likely to be killed if you carry a knife, and thus being subjected to mortality salience, will increase positive thoughts in relation to knife carrying once it is outside of their focal attention.
a)	The effect of mortality salience will be greater among those who report high behaviour-specific (knife carrying) self-esteem and cultural worldviews. 
b)	The effect of mortality salience will encourage greater risk-taking behaviours around knife carrying.

2.	Providing subjects with a message making them aware of the consequences of knife carrying on others close to them, will reverse any adverse effect of mortality salience and reduce their positive thoughts in relation to carrying a knife.

3.	However, in the present context (as of April 2020), those more affected by the Covid-19 crisis - i.e. for whom mortality is already more salient for that reason - will be less affected by the images.

attributes.title: SHARP 2019
attributes.description: This project explores the differences in negative outcomes by sexual orientation and gender minority status among Utah youth.

summary.value: In this study we were testing how the psychological mediation framework (PMF; Hatzenbuehler, 2009) might help explain why LGBTQ youth in Utah are at risk for negative outcomes. Below are our hypotheses that we sought to test and a research question we wanted to explore.

registration_responses.summary: In this study we were testing how the psychological mediation framework (PMF; Hatzenbuehler, 2009) might help explain why LGBTQ youth in Utah are at risk for negative outcomes. Below are our hypotheses that we sought to test and a research question we wanted to explore.
